content:
Hi,

I was working on a little "Intro to Span(Set) for Engineers" for my own education as well as to help motivate some other things I'm working on.

I noticed that if you have a span V:∗→∗V: *\to *V:∗→∗ where ∗*∗ is a set with one element, you can compose it with itself to get the span V×∗V:∗→∗V\times_* V: *\to *V×∗​V:∗→∗ and (unless I made a mistake) it turns out that V×∗VV\times_* VV×∗​V is just the normal Cartesian product, i.e.
{}
V×∗V=V×V.V\times_* V = V\times V.V×∗​V=V×V.
{}
I also noticed that if you have a span V:V→VV: V\to VV:V→V where the source and target are identity functions, you can compose it with itself to get the span V×VV:V→VV\times_V V: V\to VV×V​V:V→V. The set V×VVV\times_V VV×V​V consists of elements (v1,v2)∈V×V(v_1,v_2)\in V\times V(v1​,v2​)∈V×V such that t(v1)=s(v2)t(v_1) = s(v_2)t(v1​)=s(v2​), but s,ts,ts,t are just identity functions so elements of V×VVV\times_V VV×V​V are pairs (v,v)(v,v)(v,v) and (unless I made a mistake)
{}
V×VV≅VV\times_V V \cong VV×V​V≅V
{}
so that considering isomorphism classes of spans, V:V→VV:V\to VV:V→V is an identity morphism.

I thought this could be a cute way to define a product V×V→VV\times V\to VV×V→V of elements of a set by forming a commuting diagram of spans

image.png

I want to get something morally like

v1 v2={v1,if v1=v2∅,otherwise.\begin{aligned} v_1\, v_2 = \begin{cases} \quad v_1, & \text{if}\ v_1 = v_2 \\ \quad\emptyset, & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases}\end{aligned}v1​v2​={v1​,∅,​if v1​=v2​otherwise.​​

Considering isomorphism classes of spans, I want to replace that :point_of_information: diagram with

image.png

If v1=v2v_1 = v_2v1​=v2​, I think the diagram is fine, but if v1≠v2v_1\ne v_2v1​=v2​, it doesn't parse because ∅\emptyset∅ is not necessarily an element of VVV.

In desperation, I tried augmenting VVV with the empty set so I have a diagram

image.png

but this is starting to feel desparate and I'm about to accept that multiplying elements of a set via maps between spans is just a bad idea and I should drop it.

Is there any way to salvage this?

The motivation is that I am going to send my sets to algebras via a functor, i.e. V→KVV \to K^VV→KV (functions from VVV to a field KKK). In this algebra, for every element i∈Vi\in Vi∈V we have a basis function ei∈KVe^i\in K^Vei∈KV such that
{}
ei(j)=δjie^i(j) = \delta^i_jei(j)=δji​
{}
with product
{}
eiej=δi,jei.e^i e^j = \delta^{i,j} e^i.eiej=δi,jei.
{}
So I think it would be interesting if we could define this product in Span(Set)\mathsf{Span(Set)}Span(Set) in terms of commuting diagrams. Since functors preserve commuting diagrams, then if I have a rule like that in Span(Set)\mathsf{Span(Set)}Span(Set) it gets preserved if I have a functor out of Span(Set).\mathsf{Span(Set)}.Span(Set).

Any ideas? Thank you :pray:

Edit: If it matters, the first diagram above :point_of_information: is piece of a natural transformation between functors
{}
F,G:N→Span(Set)F,G: \mathbb{N}\to\mathsf{Span(Set)}F,G:N→Span(Set)
{}
so I was hoping to say something morally like, "Multiplication of elements of a set is a natural transformation."

Eric Forgy said:

Hi,

I was working on a little "Intro to Span(Set) for Engineers" for my own education as well as to help motivate some other things I'm working on.

I noticed that if you have a span V:∗→∗V: *\to *V:∗→∗ where ∗*∗ is a set with one element, you can compose it with itself to get the span V×∗V:∗→∗V\times_* V: *\to *V×∗​V:∗→∗ and (unless I made a mistake) it turns out that V×∗VV\times_* VV×∗​V is just the normal Cartesian product, i.e.
{}
V×∗V=V×V.V\times_* V = V\times V.V×∗​V=V×V.
{}

That's true! This fact is famous and can be generalized a lot.

Eric Forgy said:

I also noticed that if you have a span V:V→VV: V\to VV:V→V where the source and target are identity functions...

That's called an identity span, it's an identity morphism in the category (or bicategory) of spans. This fact explains some of your observations.

Eric Forgy said:

I thought this could be a cute way to define a product V×V→VV\times V\to VV×V→V of elements of a set by forming a commuting diagram of spans [...]

I want to get something morally like

v1 v2={v1,if v1=v2∅,otherwise.\begin{aligned} v_1\, v_2 = \begin{cases} \quad v_1, & \text{if}\ v_1 = v_2 \\ \quad\emptyset, & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases}\end{aligned}v1​v2​={v1​,∅,​if v1​=v2​otherwise.​​

That's not something you should want. First, there are only two god-given ways to give a set VVV a multiplication if we don't have any other structure to help us. One rule is this:

v1 v2=v1 v_1\, v_2 = v_1v1​v2​=v1​

and the other is this

v1 v2=v2 v_1 \, v_2 = v_2 v1​v2​=v2​

Both rules are associative, so every set naturally becomes a semigroup in two different ways.

It's obvious that there are no other ways, since (by assumption) we don't have anything else to work with.

In particular, ∅\emptyset∅ is not even an element of VVV.

On the other hand, if you want a partially defined multiplication on VVV you could decree that v1 v2v_1 \, v_2 v1​v2​ equals v1v_1v1​ when v1=v2v_1 = v_2v1​=v2​ and decree that it's undefined otherwise. This makes any set into a semigroup object in the category of sets and partially defined functions. (That's an important category.) You seem to be trying to use ∅\emptyset∅ as a stand-in for "undefined".

Note:

1) composition of morphisms in a category is partially defined, so the set of morphisms of any category becomes a semigroup object in the category of sets and partially defined maps.

2) given a semigroup object XXX in the category of sets and partially defined maps, we can always give the free vector space on XXX a product where we define the product of two elements of XXX to be zero if it's undefined. This is an associative algebra without unit.

Combining tricks 1) and 2), any category gives an associative algebra without unit. (If the category is finite, this algebra actually has a unit.)

You, Eric, sometimes do this when your category is the category of paths in a graph.

John Baez said:

You seem to be trying to use ∅\emptyset∅ as a stand-in for "undefined".

Exactly. Yeah. I didn't know how to handle "undefined" and "empty" was the closest thing I could think of (and I see your next comment on "partial stuff") :+1:

There's a lot of fun stuff to say about the category of sets and partially defined functions:

https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/partial+function#idea

John Baez said:

You, Eric, sometimes do this when your category is the category of paths in a graph.

Yeah. That is exactly what I am trying to do. I'll think about it :raised_hands:

The usual definition of product of paths in a graph as concatenation (if defined) felt a little contrived so I was trying to come up with some arrow theoretic way to show that is the only thing that makes sense.
There's nothing contrived about that.
There's a forgetful functor from Cat to Graph, and its left adjoint sends each graph to the category where morphisms are paths of edges!
That's the way to make precise this intuition: any graph gives a category where you can "freely compose" edges and get morphisms in the category.

John Baez said:

There's a forgetful functor from Cat to Graph, and its left adjoint sends each graph to the category where morphisms are paths of edges!

This sounds like the arrow theoretic justification I was looking for :blush:
Yes!

I was telling you about this a while back, right before you overloaded and told me you had to feed your family:

  1. Start with a graph G.
  2. Apply the "free category on a graph" functor F:Graph→CatF: \mathsf{Graph} \to \mathsf{Cat}F:Graph→Cat to get a category F(G)F(G)F(G) whose morphisms are paths in the graph GGG.
  3. Apply the "nerve" functor N:Cat→SSetN: \mathsf{Cat} \to \mathsf{SSet}N:Cat→SSet, which turns categories into simplicial sets. An n-simplex in N(F(G))N(F(G))N(F(G)) will be a length-n path in the graph GGG.
  4. Apply the "cochains" functor C:SSet→DGAC: \mathsf{SSet} \to \mathsf{DGA}C:SSet→DGA to create the dga of cochains on your simplicial set.
Step 2 is the left adjoint we're talking about right now.
Btw, it's completely normal to overload and "shut down" when learning category theory. I do it all the time. There's just a limit to how much abstraction anyone can swallow in one sitting!
It becomes downright painful... that means it's time to take a break.
Thank you for your help and thank you for your understanding :raised_hands:

I've "hit the wall" so many times learning category theory, I know this is just part of the process. I actually think it involves growing new neurons - there's a kind of physical pain involved. (But then when you understand things it's lots of fun.)

That is very helpful for me too. I have slowly been growing the neurons for the concept of Simplicial Set by following work on higher dimensional networks and tying it to RDF. (I still need to learn about this "nerve" functor, which I noticed turns up a lot). Step 3 now looks very intriguing.
I wonder if those 4 steps are an answer to @Jacques Carette 's question in the underlying graphs thread on Zulip which arose from his experience building a proof relevant Category Theory library in Agda. (see StackExchange question).

John Baez said:

There's a lot of fun stuff to say about the category of sets and partially defined functions:

https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/partial+function#idea

I actually had this page open :+1:

(but obviously hadn't absorbed it yet :sweat_smile: )

In particular:

The category Setpart\mathsf{Set_{part}}Setpart​ of sets and partial functions between them is important for understanding computation.

I'm also looking at: https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/partial+map+classifier

This looks like what I was trying to do (I was on the fence whether to use ∪\cup∪ or ∐\coprod∐):

A partial function f:A⇀Bf:A⇀Bf:A⇀B between two sets can be turned into a total function fˉ:A→B⊥\bar{f}:A→B_⊥fˉ​:A→B⊥​ by adding a new element ⊥⊥⊥ to BBB and sending all a∈Aa∈Aa∈A that are not in the domain of definition of fff to this new value ⊥⊥⊥ = “undefined” and the rest just to their value under fff.

I don't think it matters what you use for "undefined", but some symbol is probably better than ∅\emptyset∅ :+1:

This also looks interesting: https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/maybe+monad

I'm not yet ready to give up on this idea of defining a product of elements of a set like

v1 v2={v1,if v1=v2⊥ i.e. “undefined”,otherwise.\begin{aligned} v_1\, v_2 = \begin{cases} \quad v_1, & \text{if}\ v_1 = v_2 \\ \quad\perp\,\text{i.e. ``undefined''}, & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases}\end{aligned}v1​v2​={v1​,⊥i.e. “undefined”,​if v1​=v2​otherwise.​​

but I need some nice diagram to express it :thinking:

John Baez said:

  1. Start with a graph G.
  2. Apply the "free category on a graph" functor F:Graph→CatF: \mathsf{Graph} \to \mathsf{Cat}F:Graph→Cat to get a category F(G)F(G)F(G) whose morphisms are paths in the graph GGG.
  3. Apply the "nerve" functor N:Cat→SSetN: \mathsf{Cat} \to \mathsf{SSet}N:Cat→SSet, which turns categories into simplicial sets. An n-simplex in N(F(G))N(F(G))N(F(G)) will be a length-n path in the graph GGG.
  4. Apply the "cochains" functor C:SSet→DGAC: \mathsf{SSet} \to \mathsf{DGA}C:SSet→DGA to create the dga of cochains on your simplicial set.

I know I am being stubborn, but I am trying to do something like this, but with steps 1. and 2. replaced by a functor
{}
G:N→Span(Set)G: \mathbb{N}\to\mathsf{Span(Set)}G:N→Span(Set)
{}
I like this because each n∈Nn\in\mathbf{N}n∈N maps to directed paths of length nnn (G(1)G(1)G(1) is a directed graph as an endomorphism) directly and is more closely related to the next category I'm looking at, which is

  • Objects are algebras
  • Morphisms are isomorphism classes of bimodules
  • 2-morphisms are bimodule morphisms

The whole picture (still ironing it out) is

N→Span(Set)→Span(Alg)→Ch∙,\mathbb{N}\to\mathsf{Span(Set)}\to\mathsf{Span(Alg)}\to \mathsf{Ch}^\bullet,N→Span(Set)→Span(Alg)→Ch∙,

where the last step is cochain complexes. This is very intuitive to me.

It isn't necessary to get a product

vi vj={vi,if i=j⊥ i.e. “undefined”,otherwise.\begin{aligned} v_i\, v_j = \begin{cases} \quad v_i, & \text{if}\ i = j \\ \quad\perp\,\text{i.e. ``undefined''}, & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases}\end{aligned}vi​vj​={vi​,⊥i.e. “undefined”,​if i=jotherwise.​​

in Span(Set)\mathsf{Span(Set)}Span(Set), but the product in Span(Alg)\mathsf{Span(Alg)}Span(Alg) is of that form, i.e.

ei ej={ei,if i=j0,otherwise.\begin{aligned} e^i\, e^j = \begin{cases} \quad e^i, & \text{if}\ i = j \\ \quad 0, & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases}\end{aligned}eiej={ei,0,​if i=jotherwise.​​

It just seems like there should be a clean way to do this with commuting diagrams with ⊥↦0.\perp\mapsto 0.⊥↦0.

Btw, vertices are thought of as paths of length 0. The corresponding product of edges (spans) is

ϵi ϵj={(ϵi,ϵj)∈E×VEif t(ϵi)=s(ϵj)⊥ i.e. “undefined”,otherwise\begin{aligned} \epsilon_i\, \epsilon_j = \begin{cases} \quad (\epsilon_i,\epsilon_j)\in E\times_V E & \text{if}\ t(\epsilon_i) =s(\epsilon_j) \\ \quad\perp\,\text{i.e. ``undefined''}, & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}\end{aligned}ϵi​ϵj​={(ϵi​,ϵj​)∈E×V​E⊥i.e. “undefined”,​if t(ϵi​)=s(ϵj​)otherwise​​

with the obvious generalization to directed paths.

Btw^2, the second functor Span(Set)→Span(Alg)\mathsf{Span(Set)\to Span(Alg)}Span(Set)→Span(Alg) maps

  • V↦KVV\mapsto K^VV↦KV (which is an algebra)
  • (V←E→V)↦(KV←KE→KV)(V\leftarrow E\rightarrow V)\mapsto (K^V\leftarrow K^E\rightarrow K^V)(V←E→V)↦(KV←KE→KV) (which is a (KV,KV)(K^V,K^V)(KV,KV)-bimodule)

What that thread says about the underlying graph functor is that it doesn't respect categorical equivalence. Which does make it a rather bad functor indeed, as it can see fine structure that isn't visible in context (i.e. there are equivalent categories, in the 2-category of categories, which the underlying graph functor sends to inequivalent graphs).

But all that means for its adjoint is that it isn't faithful. Not a big deal.

I can't help but wonder if the nerve functor is well-behaved though.

@Eric Forgy I'm only partially following this discussion. Is this what you mean by a functor GGG?
-It maps from the category freely generated by starting with a single object ∗*∗ and a single non-identity morphism +1+1+1 on it
-It sends the single object to a set of vertices G(∗)G(*)G(∗), and the generating morphism to a graph (endospan) G(+1)G(+1)G(+1) on that set
-Composition of morphisms in Span(Set)\mathsf{Span(Set)}Span(Set) corresponds to pullbacks of the apex (arrow) sets with respect to the source and target functions of the corresponding graphs. This involves taking a subset of the cartesian product of the apex sets, requiring each ordered pair in the result to satisfy the condition that the target of the first element matches the source of the second element. So, G(+2)=G(+1)G(+1)G(+2) = G(+1)G(+1)G(+2)=G(+1)G(+1) corresponds to the paths of length 2 in the graph G(+1)G(+1)G(+1).
-In general G(+n)G(+n)G(+n) is the paths of length nnn on the graph G(+1)G(+1)G(+1).
That is exactly right David :+1::blush:

Intuitively, that makes sense. I understand functors as often generating a "best interpretation of the source in the target context". The source in this case is a category that is all about relating a thing to itself in ways generated by one non-trivial way. The functor then picks a single set to relate to itself, and then picks a single generating non-trivial self-relationship on that set - namely the graph G(+1)G(+1)G(+1). Given a way of composing this self-relationship (in this case we chose to do this by concatenating compatible arrows into paths), this then generates a sequence of additional self-relationships on the set (the paths of higher order on G(+1)G(+1)G(+1)).

I don't (yet) know enough algebra to follow what you are saying about modules. I'd appreciate it if you could describe the equivalent to "graphs" you are trying to generate in some simpler terms. Maybe in terms of vector spaces?

Eric Forgy said:

Btw^2, the second functor Span(Set)→Span(Alg)\mathsf{Span(Set)\to Span(Alg)}Span(Set)→Span(Alg) maps

  • V↦KVV\mapsto K^VV↦KV (which is an algebra)
  • (V←E→V)↦(KV←KE→KV)(V\leftarrow E\rightarrow V)\mapsto (K^V\leftarrow K^E\rightarrow K^V)(V←E→V)↦(KV←KE→KV) (which is a (KV,KV)(K^V,K^V)(KV,KV)-bimodule)

I see. Where before we had a set of vertices, now we have the functions on that set to some field (assuming VVV is a set and KKK is a field), which forms an "algebra" with "scalar" multiplication of functions by KKK and multiplications of functions with functions presumably corresponding to element-wise multiplication, so (fg)(x)=f(x)g(x)(fg)(x) = f(x)g(x)(fg)(x)=f(x)g(x).
Before, to make a graph we introduced another set, and associated it in two ways with the set of interest.
Now, we are introducing another algebra of functions and associating it in two ways with our algebra of functions of interest.

David Egolf said:

I don't (yet) know enough algebra to follow what you are saying about modules. I'd appreciate it if you could describe the equivalent to "graphs" you are trying to generate in some simpler terms. Maybe in terms of vector spaces?

Oh dear, I am not the best person (especially among this crowd) to explain modules, but as one engineer to another, modules are a lot like vector spaces. You can add modules together. You can tensor them (if they meet the "apex" condition), but instead of scalar multiplication, you have "ring action". You usually don't talk about "modules", you talk about "(left or right) RRR-modules" or, like in my case, "(R,S)(R,S)(R,S)-bimodules". In my case, I have more than just rings, I have commutative associative algebras (which are also rings) so I deal with AAA-bimodules (which is short for (A,A)(A,A)(A,A)-bimodule). In my case, I have an AAA-bimodule denoted Ω\OmegaΩ. This means with two elements f,g∈Af,g\in Af,g∈A and α∈Ω\alpha\in \Omegaα∈Ω, fff and ggg can act on α\alphaα (which I think of as multiplying on the left and right) giving a new module element f α g∈Ω1.f\,\alpha\, g\in\Omega^1.fαg∈Ω1.

The "apex" condition for tensor product of modules means that if you have an (R,S)(R,S)(R,S)-bimodule Ω\OmegaΩ and an (S,T)(S,T)(S,T)-bimodule Ω′\Omega'Ω′ you can tensor them over SSS resulting in a new (R,T)(R,T)(R,T)-bimodule Ω⊗SΩ′\Omega\otimes_S \Omega'Ω⊗S​Ω′.

Or, in my case, I have an AAA-bimodule Ω\OmegaΩ so I can tensor it with itself to get a new AAA-bimodule Ω⊗AΩ\Omega\otimes_A\OmegaΩ⊗A​Ω. I can repeat this getting AAA-bimodules Ω⊗An.\Omega^{\otimes_A n}.Ω⊗A​n.

This is VERY reminiscent of what happens with a functor G:N→Span(Set)G:\mathbb{N}\to\mathsf{Span(Set)}G:N→Span(Set). A directed graph G(1)=E:V→VG(1) = E:V\to VG(1)=E:V→V as an endomorphism in Span(Set)\mathsf{Span(Set)}Span(Set) can be composed with itself nnn times resulting in G(n)=G(1)×Vn.G(n) = G(1)^{\times_V n}.G(n)=G(1)×V​n.

An AAA-bimodule Ω\OmegaΩ can be thought of as an endomorphism in Span(Alg)\mathsf{Span(Alg)}Span(Alg), i.e. a span A←Ω→A.A\leftarrow\Omega\rightarrow A.A←Ω→A.

This is what my functor
{}
Span(Set)→Span(Alg)\mathsf{Span(Set)\to Span(Alg)}Span(Set)→Span(Alg)
{}
does. It takes a span (directed graph)
{}
V←E→VV\leftarrow E\rightarrow VV←E→V
{}
and sends it to the span (KVK^VKV-bimodule)
{}
KV←KE→KV.K^V\leftarrow K^E\rightarrow K^V.KV←KE→KV.

Since a functor
{}
G:N→Span(Set)G: \mathbb{N}\to\mathsf{Span(Set)}G:N→Span(Set)
{}
is completely determined by what it does to the one object ∗*∗ in N\mathbb{N}N and what it does to the morphism 111 in N\mathbb{N}N, i.e.
{}
G(∙)=VG(\bullet) = VG(∙)=V and G(1):E:V→VG(1): E: V\to VG(1):E:V→V
{}
the functor is basically a directed graph (as an endomorphism in Span(Set)).\mathsf{Span(Set)}).Span(Set)).
So writing
{}
N→Span(Set)→Span(Alg)\mathbb{N}\to\mathsf{Span(Set)\to Span(Alg)}N→Span(Set)→Span(Alg)
{}
tells us that starting with a directed graph E:V→VE:V\to VE:V→V, we can construct an AAA-bimodule Ω\OmegaΩ with A=KV.A = K^V.A=KV.
Thanks for explaining! I'll have to meditate on how "paths" on bimodules relate to something more concrete.

Coming full circle...

As you correctly noted, KVK^VKV is the algebra of functions V→KV\to KV→K for some field KKK with product defined pointwise, i.e.
{}
(f g)(i)=f(i) g(i).(f\,g)(i) = f(i)\,g(i).(fg)(i)=f(i)g(i).
{}
But, since AAA is constructed from a set VVV, it means the elements of the set i∈Vi\in Vi∈V correspond to basis elements in AAA I denote as eie^iei such that
{}
ei(j)=δjie^i(j) = \delta^i_jei(j)=δji​
{}
which gives us the product of basis elements as
{}
(ei ej)(k)=δki δkj,(e^i\, e^j)(k) = \delta^i_k\,\delta^j_k,(eiej)(k)=δki​δkj​,
{}
which can be written as
{}
ei ej=δi,jeie^i\,e^j = \delta^{i,j} e^ieiej=δi,jei
{}
or in other words
{}
ei ej={ei,if i=j0,otherwise.\begin{aligned} e^i\, e^j = \begin{cases} \quad e^i, & \text{if}\ i = j \\ \quad 0, & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases}\end{aligned}eiej={ei,0,​if i=jotherwise.​​
{}
However, since I have this nice functor Span(Set)→Span(Alg)\mathsf{Span(Set)\to Span(Alg)}Span(Set)→Span(Alg), I'm wondering if I can move this product back to Span(Set)\mathsf{Span(Set)}Span(Set)
{}
vi vj={vi,if i=j⊥ i.e. “undefined”,otherwise.\begin{aligned} v_i\, v_j = \begin{cases} \quad v_i, & \text{if}\ i = j \\ \quad\perp\,\text{i.e. ``undefined''}, & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases}\end{aligned}vi​vj​={vi​,⊥i.e. “undefined”,​if i=jotherwise.​​
{}
but define it as a commuting diagram so that when I hit it with my functor Span(Set)→Span(Alg)\mathsf{Span(Set)\to Span(Alg)}Span(Set)→Span(Alg), we get the same product I know I want in Span(Alg).\mathsf{Span(Alg)}.Span(Alg). This step isn't absolutely necessary because there is a natural way to get the product directly in Span(Alg)\mathsf{Span(Alg)}Span(Alg) as described above, BUT it would be nice I think so I'm still trying to figure out a nice way to do it.

David Egolf said:

Thanks for explaining! I'll have to meditate on how "paths" on bimodules relate to something more concrete.

Once you understand that, you are well on your way to understanding discrete differential geometry (which is the point of all this) :+1: :blush:

A general element f∈A=KVf\in A = K^Vf∈A=KV can be written as
{}
f=∑i∈Vf(i) eif = \sum_{i\in V} f(i)\, e^if=∑i∈V​f(i)ei
{}
These are "discrete 0-forms".
A general element α∈Ω=KE\alpha\in\Omega = K^Eα∈Ω=KE can be written as
{}
α=∑ϵ∈Eα(ϵ) eϵ\alpha = \sum_{\epsilon\in E} \alpha(\epsilon)\, e^\epsilonα=∑ϵ∈E​α(ϵ)eϵ
{}
These are "discrete 1-forms".
A general element β∈Ω⊗AΩ\beta\in\Omega\otimes_A\Omegaβ∈Ω⊗A​Ω can be written as
{}
β=∑(ϵ1,ϵ2)∈E×VEβ(ϵ1,ϵ2) eϵ1⊗Aϵ2\beta = \sum_{(\epsilon_1,\epsilon_2)\in E\times_V E} \beta(\epsilon_1,\epsilon_2)\, e^{\epsilon_1\otimes_A \epsilon_2}β=∑(ϵ1​,ϵ2​)∈E×V​E​β(ϵ1​,ϵ2​)eϵ1​⊗A​ϵ2​
{}
These are NOT "discrete 2-forms".

John Baez said:

  1. Start with a graph G.
  2. Apply the "free category on a graph" functor F:Graph→CatF: \mathsf{Graph} \to \mathsf{Cat}F:Graph→Cat to get a category F(G)F(G)F(G) whose morphisms are paths in the graph GGG.
  3. Apply the "nerve" functor N:Cat→SSetN: \mathsf{Cat} \to \mathsf{SSet}N:Cat→SSet, which turns categories into simplicial sets. An n-simplex in N(F(G))N(F(G))N(F(G)) will be a length-n path in the graph GGG.
  4. Apply the "cochains" functor C:SSet→DGAC: \mathsf{SSet} \to \mathsf{DGA}C:SSet→DGA to create the dga of cochains on your simplicial set.

The functor
{}
N→Span(Set)\mathbb{N}\to\mathsf{Span(Set)}N→Span(Set)
{}

I think the elegant way to do what you're suggesting is this. Note that given a field KKK, the functor

Set→Alg\mathsf{Set} \to \mathsf{Alg}Set→Alg

sending a set SSS to the algebra KSK^SKS is contravariant, as I mentioned. That is, a function f:S→Tf: S \to Tf:S→T gives an algebra homomorphism f∗:KT→KSf^\ast : K^T \to K^Sf∗:KT→KS, defined by

f∗(g)=g∘ff ^\ast (g) = g \circ ff∗(g)=g∘f

for g∈KTg \in K^Tg∈KT. Thus, this functor maps a span of sets

S←X→TS \leftarrow X \to TS←X→T

to a cospan of algebras

KS→KX→KT K^S \to K^X \to K^TKS→KX→KT

In particular, any graph is an endospan of sets

V←E→V V \leftarrow E \to VV←E→V

so it gets send to an endo-cospan of algebras

KV→KE←KV K^V \rightarrow K^E \leftarrow K^VKV→KE←KV

By the way, the categories we're dealing with - like Set and Alg - are not compact closed. The most famous compact closed category is the category of finite-dimensional vector spaces made monoidal with the usual ⊗\otimes⊗.

The categories Set and Alg also do not have biproducts. CommAlg, the category of commutative algebras, has biproducts: ⊗\otimes⊗ is the biproduct of commutative algebras. Note that your algebras KSK^SKS are commutative, and you might want to take advantage of that.
Yeah. I am always (so far) dealing with commutative (associative, unital) algebras :+1:
Actually scratch that - it's bullshit. The category of commutative algebras does NOT have biproducts.
It has products and coproducts, but they are different: in a category with biproducts (like Vect) they are the same.

Not really: one problem is that you're only telling us how to multiply amba m bamb and a′m′b′a' m' b'a′m′b′ in the special case where m=m′m = m'm=m′, so it's not really a well-defined product!

The other problem is that everything about your formula for multiplication is just multiplication in AAA and in BBB, nothing about the bimodule.

So you practically might as well just leave out the bimodule and admit you're making A⊗BA \otimes BA⊗B into an algebra - that is a something you can really do.
If you grab a book like Rings and Categories of Modules you can learn what's possible (and thus what's not).
